elements.content: A series of silver(I) complexes with semirigid di-2-pyrimidyl sulfide (DprS), namely, {[Ag2(DprS)2(CF3CO2)](CF3CO2)·2H2O}∞ (1), {[Ag6(DprS)6(CF3SO3)5](CF3SO3)·3.5H2O}∞ (2), {[Ag2(DprS)(C2F5CO2)2]}∞ (3), [Ag(DprS)(NO3)∞ (4), and {[Ag3(DprS)3](ClO4)3}∞ (5), have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray analysis. The silver(I) complexes 1–2 and 4–5 exhibit one-dimensional tape-like coordination polymers with different topological structures, while complex 3 has a two-dimensional coordination network. In these complexes, the two pyrimidyl rings of each DprS are almost in an orthogonal orientation, a rigid nonplanar conformation, and the multidentate ligand adopts an unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode despite the different anions (CH3COO– in 1, CF3SO3 – in 2, C2F5COO– in 3, NO3 – in 4, and ClO4 – in 5). Attractive intramolecular Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl interaction between a 1-positional N atom of one pyrimidyl ring and an electrophilic 2-positional C atom of the other ring of DprS is a common dominant interaction, which drives and stabilizes the nonplanar ligand conformation in these crystalline structures. Calculation through the self-consistent field crystal orbital method based on density functional theory indicates the presence of the N···C contact, a nucleophile–electrophile affinity. Unconventional anion−πpyrimidyl interactions engaged in the construction of the supramolecular architectures of 1–5 also are presented and discussed.

Calculation through the self-consistent field crystal orbital method based on density functional theory indicates the presence of the N⋅⋅⋅C contact, a nucleophile-electrophile affinity. elements.content: Attractive intramolecular N···C interaction of di-2-pyrimidyl sulfide functions as a common dominant interaction to drive and stabilize the nonplanar ligand to take an unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging mode in a series of one-dimensional tape-like and two-dimensional net silver(I) coordination frameworks in the solid state. Intramolecular anion−πpyrimidyl interactions play an important role in the supramolecular aggregations of these complexes.

Intramolecular anion-πpyrimidyl interactions play an important role in the supramolecular aggregations of these complexes.

elements.content: Chalcogenobispyridines and derivates display a wide range of biological and industrial applications, as well as provide building blocks for supramolecular assembly. In contrast to linear ligands such as 4,4′-bipyridine, semirigid di-2-pyridyl sulfide (DpS) and its N-positional isomers bearing the rotatable C(sp2)–S bond and the variable C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle (∼100°) exhibit more flexible ligation modes in the construction of diverse coordination motifs with unusual properties. The geometric chemistry along with the dynamic process as the stereodemanded DpS ligand bonds to the octahedral metal center has also attracted more attention. The ab initio and density functional theory (DFT) calculations by Bruno et al. also indicated that the presence and position of other N atoms introduced on the rings of DpS would mostly influence the minimum energy conformation of such N-rich heterocyclic sulfides. Recently, some flexible multimodal thioether ligands, such as bis(2-pyrazylmethyl)sulfide, 2-benzylsulfanylmethylpyrazine, and bis(4-pyrimidylmethyl)sulfide, were reported because of the interesting anion–pyrimidyl interactions in their supramolecular metal–organic frameworks. However, the certain ligand behavior of the N-rich diheterocyclic derivative of DpS in the construction of metal–organic frameworks was seldom reported until now.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chalcogenobispyridines and derivates display a wide range of biological and industrial applications, as well as provide building blocks for supramolecular assembly. In contrast to linear ligands such as 4,4'-bipyridine, semirigid di-2-pyridyl sulfide (DpS) and its N-positional isomers bearing the rotatable C(sp2)-S bond and the variable C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angle (~100°) exhibit more flexible ligation modes in the construction of diverse coordination motifs with unusual properties. The geometric chemistry along with the dynamic process as the stereodemanded DpS ligand bonds to the octahedral metal center has also attracted more attention. The ab initio and density functional theory (DFT) calculations by Bruno et al. also indicated that the presence and position of other N atoms introduced on the rings of DpS would mostly influence the minimum energy conformation of such N-rich heterocyclic sulfides. Recently, some flexible multimodal thioether ligands, such as bis(2-pyrazylmethyl)sulfide, 2-benzylsulfanylmethylpyrazine, and bis(4-pyrimidylmethyl)sulfide, were reported because of the interesting anion-pyrimidyl interactions in their supramolecular metal-organic frameworks. However, the certain ligand behavior of the N-rich diheterocyclic derivative of DpS in the construction of metal-organic frameworks was seldom reported until now.

elements.content: Our recent interest focuses on the study of N-rich diheterocyclic ligands and their related unconventional anion−π and/or lone pair–aromatic interactions in the construction of supramolecular architectures with their metal complexes. In order to conduct a certain investigation of the ligand behavior of the N-rich diheterocyclic sulfide derivative in its crystalline metal–organic complex, in the present context we report the diheterocyclic sulfide ligand incorporating a pair of pyrimidyl rings, namely, di-2-pyrimidyl sulfide (DprS, Scheme ), and its silver(I) complexes (1–5), namely, {[Ag2(DprS)2(CF3CO2)](CF3CO2)·2H2O}∞ (1), {[Ag6(DprS)6(CF3SO3)5](CF3SO3)·3.5H2O}∞ (2), {[Ag2(DprS)(C2F5CO2)2]}∞ (3), [Ag(DprS)(NO3)∞ (4), and {[Ag3(DprS)3](ClO4)3}∞ (5), all of which were characterized by X-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, emission property, and elemental analyses. 1–2 and 4–5 exhibit one-dimensional (1-D) tape-like coordination motifs, while 3 has a two-dimensional (2-D) net structure. The attractive contact between one 1-positional N atom and one 2-positional C atom of the opposite ring of DprS is a common dominant interaction (N···C 2.729(2)–2.911(5) Å, Scheme ) in these crystalline structures. The multidentate ligand thus adopts an unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode. The variations of the DprS dimensions (S–C(sp2) bond length, C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle, N···C distance, etc.) that are beyond the molecular packing in complexes 1–5 are compared and discussed. The unconventional anion−πpyrimidyl interactions that engage in the construction of the supramolecular architectures of complexes 1–5 are also presented and discussed.

elements.content: All organic reagents were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. All the metal salts were obtained from commercial sources. Ligand di-2-pyrimidyl sulfide (DprS) was synthesized according to reported procedures. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed using an Elemental Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer with dry KBr pellet in the range of 400–4000 cm–1. Fluorescence spectra were measured on a F-4500FL spectrophotometer in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All organic reagents were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. All the metal salts were obtained from commercial sources. Ligand di-2-pyrimidyl sulfide (DprS) was synthesized according to reported procedures. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed using an Elemental Vario EL analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Equinox 55 FT-IR spectrometer with dry KBr pellet in the range of 400-4000 cm-1. Fluorescence spectra were measured on a F-4500FL spectrophotometer in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Calculations

The calculation is performed by the use B3LYP hybrid density functional implemented in the CRYSTAL06 program. For silver, Hay-Wadt small core effective core potential is used, and standard 6-21G(d,p) basis sets are adopted for all other elements.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of complexes 1–5 were collected on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer, operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Each selected crystal was mounted inside a Lindemann glass capillary, and each data reduction was performed using the SMART and SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. The ordered non-hydrogen atoms in each structure were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, while the hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and allowed to ride on the relevant carbon atoms. All positions of the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 1 and 2 cannot be defined even in high resolution and thus are not included in the formula refinement. In complex 1, O1W behaves normally, while the O2W is disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1. In 2, O4w exhibits two site occupancies with the ratio of 1:1, and O3w partially occupies the fractional site in 50%. The S8 and O6 atoms of one triflate are respectively disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1, while the C50 atom is disordered over two sites occupancies (C50 and C50') with a ratio of 0.6:0.4. In complex 5, the S3, Ag3 atoms and one pyrimidyl ring (N9–C17–C18–C19–N10–C20) are disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1, respectively. The detailed crystal data of 1–5 are listed in Table , and CCDC numbers 746712 (1), 746713 (2), 746714 (3), 826038(4), 826039(5) contain the supplementary crystal data for complexes 1–5, which can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

X-ray Crystallographic Studies

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of complexes 1-5 were collected on a Bruker APEX II CCD diffractometer, operating at 50 kV and 30 mA using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Each selected crystal was mounted inside a Lindemann glass capillary, and each data reduction was performed using the SMART and SAINT software. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL program package. The ordered non-hydrogen atoms in each structure were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters, while the hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and allowed to ride on the relevant carbon atoms. All positions of the hydrogen atoms of the water molecules in 1 and 2 cannot be defined even in high resolution and thus are not included in the formula refinement. In complex 1, O1W behaves normally, while the O2W is disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1. In 2, O4w exhibits two site occupancies with the ratio of 1:1, and O3w partially occupies the fractional site in 50%. The S8 and O6 atoms of one triflate are respectively disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1, while the C50 atom is disordered over two sites occupancies (C50 and C50') with a ratio of 0.6:0.4. In complex 5, the S3, Ag3 atoms and one pyrimidyl ring (N9-C17-C18-C19-N10-C20) are disordered at two positions with a ratio of 1:1, respectively. The detailed crystal data of 1-5 are listed in Table , and CCDC numbers 746712 (1), 746713 (2), 746714 (3), 826038(4), 826039(5) contain the supplementary crystal data for complexes 1-5, which can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

In the crystalline structures of complexes 1–5, each multidentate DprS adopts a preferential N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging mode with the two pyrimidyl rings almost in an orthogonal orientation. Structure analysis reveals that attractive intramolecular Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl interaction (N···C distances 2.729(2)–2.911(5) Å) between one 1-positional N of one pyrimidyl ring and one 2-positional C atom from the opposite ring is a common dominant contact, which drives and stabilizes that nonplanar conformation of the DprS ligand (Scheme ). Thus, the DprS adopts an unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging mode in the infinite tape-like (1–2, 4–5) and the 2-D net (3) coordination frameworks. The ligand-building blocks bearing the necessary encoded information are widely applied in the construction of predicted supramolecular structures. Herein, the strong intramolecular Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl interaction of the semirigid DprS restricts the rotation of the pyrimidyl rings around the S–C(sp2) single bonds, which account well for the common N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode in 1–5. The variation trend of the N···C distances is along with that of the S–C(sp2) bond lengths, C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angles, and dihedral angles between two pyrimidyl rings of DprS. To facilitate subsequent discussion, we define the S–C(sp2) bond linked to the ring of the N moiety of the Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl contact as D1, while that to the ring of the C moiety of the Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl contact as D2. D refers to the Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl distance, and τ refers to the N–C–S–C′ torsion angle, as shown in Table . The fact is that the shorter D is, the smaller the C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle is, and a dihedral angle is closer to 90°. For example, the S4-containing DprS of complex 2 has the shortest D of 2.729(2) Å, the smallest C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle of 97.8(3)°, and the largest dihedral of 87.62(3)° close to 90° (Table ). The fact indicates that the conformation with two pyrimidyl rings in an orthogonal orientation (dihedral angle of 90°) is favorable for the intramolecular N···C contact of DprS, engendering the shorter D and the smaller C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle. Furthermore, the values of D1 (1.734(1)–1.780(4) Å) commonly are shorter than these of D2 (1.783(1)–1.798(6) Å) (Table ) due to the effect of the intramolecular N···C affinity. In complex 5, the D1 (1.734(1) Å) of the S2-containing DprS exhibits 0.062 Å much less than D2 (1.796(1) Å). All the D values (2.729(2)–2.911(5) Å) are well below the sum of involved atoms van der Waals radii (3.220 Å) based on Pauling’s value (C 1.72, N 1.50 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Conformation Restriction of DprS in Ag(I) Complexes 1-5 

In the crystalline structures of complexes 1-5, each multidentate DprS adopts a preferential N,N',N"-μ3 bridging mode with the two pyrimidyl rings almost in an orthogonal orientation. Structure analysis reveals that attractive intramolecular Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl interaction (N⋅⋅⋅C distances 2.729(2)-2.911(5) Å) between one 1-positional N of one pyrimidyl ring and one 2-positional C atom from the opposite ring is a common dominant contact, which drives and stabilizes that nonplanar conformation of the DprS ligand (Scheme ). Thus, the DprS adopts an unvaried N,N',N"-μ3 bridging mode in the infinite tape-like (1-2, 4-5) and the 2-D net (3) coordination frameworks. The ligand-building blocks bearing the necessary encoded information are widely applied in the construction of predicted supramolecular structures. Herein, the strong intramolecular Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl interaction of the semirigid DprS restricts the rotation of the pyrimidyl rings around the S-C(sp2) single bonds, which account well for the common N,N',N"-μ3 ligation mode in 1-5. The variation trend of the N⋅⋅⋅C distances is along with that of the S-C(sp2) bond lengths, C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angles, and dihedral angles between two pyrimidyl rings of DprS. To facilitate subsequent discussion, we define the S-C(sp2) bond linked to the ring of the N moiety of the Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl contact as D1, while that to the ring of the C moiety of the Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl contact as D2. D refers to the Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl distance, and τ refers to the N-C-S-C' torsion angle, as shown in Table . The fact is that the shorter D is, the smaller the C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angle is, and a dihedral angle is closer to 90°. For example, the S4-containing DprS of complex 2 has the shortest D of 2.729(2) Å, the smallest C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angle of 97.8(3)°, and the largest dihedral of 87.62(3)° close to 90° (Table ). The fact indicates that the conformation with two pyrimidyl rings in an orthogonal orientation (dihedral angle of 90°) is favorable for the intramolecular N⋅⋅⋅C contact of DprS, engendering the shorter D and the smaller C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angle. Furthermore, the values of D1 (1.734(1)-1.780(4) Å) commonly are shorter than these of D2 (1.783(1)-1.798(6) Å) (Table ) due to the effect of the intramolecular N⋅⋅⋅C affinity. In complex 5, the D1 (1.734(1) Å) of the S2-containing DprS exhibits 0.062 Å much less than D2 (1.796(1) Å). All the D values (2.729(2)-2.911(5) Å) are well below the sum of involved atoms van der Waals radii (3.220 Å) based on Pauling's value (C 1.72, N 1.50 Å).

τ refers to the N–C–S-C′ torsion angles.

Various anions are capable of playing an important role in the construction of supramolecular architectures through the subtle tuning effect of their bonding abilities and/or structural geometries as bonds to metal ions. The anion-controlled self-assembly by use of the attractive anion−π interaction also has been reported in several recent literature sources. In complexes 1–5, the similar CF3CO2 – (1), CF3SO3 – (2), and C2F5CO2 – (3) have a stronger bonding ability relative to NO3 – (4) and ClO4 – (5). Two similar 1-D tape-like coordination polymers with different topological structures were formed in 1 and 2, while a 2-D network was obtained in 3 with the C2F5CO2 – functioning as flexible η1:η1:μ2- and η1:η2:μ3-bridging coligands. Except for the tuning effect of C2F5CO2 –, the 2:1 ratio of Ag/DprS may also account for the extended 2-D structures of 3 as compared with 1 and 2 (1:1 ratio). For complex 4 (NO3 –), a 1-D ladder-like coordination polymer is formed. Interestingly, complex 5 exhibits the same 1-D topological tape-like structure as complex 2, despite the different bonding abilities and geometries between the CF3SO3 – (2) and ClO4 – (5). But the DprS of all the silver(I) complexes exhibits the same N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode. Apparently, the various anions (CF3CO2 – (1), CF3SO3 – (2), C2F5CO2 – (3), NO3 – (4), ClO4 – (5)) exhibit less directing effects on the ligand behavior. In these crystalline structures, the unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode of the nonplanar DprS can be ascribed to the conformation restriction of the semirigid DprS derived by the intramolecular N···C interaction and the flexible coordination geometry of Ag(I). Anion−πpyrimidyl contact functions as a common intermolecular interaction and affects the precise microarchitecture of these supramolecular aggregations of complexes 1–5, as discussed below.

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. The Ag(I) ions exhibit a distorted tetrahedral N 4-coordination geometry (Ag1) and a planar triangular N2O-coordination geometry (Ag2) in the asymmetric unit. As shown in Figure a, each Ag1 ion is surrounded by four N atoms from separated DprS ligands, while the Ag2 bonds to two N atoms from two DprS ligands and one trifluoroacetate O atom. Regarding the N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging DprS ligand, structural scrutiny reveals two sets of molecular dimensions (S1- and S2-containing DprS) in 1 with different N···C (D) distances (2.745(2) Å, 2.830(1) Å) (see Table ). For the conformation of DprS, the two pyrimidyl rings of each DprS are almost in an orthogonal orientation (dihedral angles 85.82(1)°, 81.59(1)°), and the absolute values of τ torsion angles are about 8° (−7.8(1), 8.1(1)°). The S1-containing DprS has the shorter D of 2.745(2) Å, the smaller C(sp 2 )–S–C(sp 2 ) angle of 97.49(2)°, and a dihedral angle of 85.82(1)° closer to 90°, compared to that of the S2-containing DprS (the corresponding values are 2.830(1) Å, 100.17(2)°, and 81.59(1)°, Table ). Such a conformation with the two pyrimidyl rings almost in an orthogonal orientation and a short Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl contact is similar to that in the free phenyl-pyridyl sulfide (PhpyS) and pyrimidyl-pyridyl sulfide (PrpyS) indicated by Bruno et al. (N···C distance: 2.894 Å in PrpyS, 2.932 Å in PhpyS). For the S–C(sp2) bonds (D1, D2), each C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) moiety exhibits a D1 slight shorter than D2 (Table ).

elements.content: An infinite tape-like structure with the N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging DprS ligands and silver(I) ions (Ag1 and Ag2) is furnished along the a axis. Treating the ligand as a 3-connected node, the Ag atoms each as a node, a 1-D topological structure of 1 is shown in Figure b. The formed cationic tape structures are arranged in a shoulder-to-shoulder mode and interconnect via π···π (centroid···centroid 4.036 Å) and O(CF3CO2 –)−πpyrimidy interactions (Figure ), leading to a network in the ab plane. For the anion−π interaction, the trifluoracetate (O2-containing) bound to the Ag2 ion points to pyrimidyl rings of the opposite tape with one F11 atom and an O1 atom exhibiting F···pyrimidyl and O···pyrimidyl affinities, respectively. As shown in Figure , the F11 atom is embedded by two pyrimidyl rings with the F···centroidpyrimidyl of 3.151 Å and 3.213 Å, respectively. The O1 atom points to the third ring at the O···centroidpyrimidyl of 3.469 Å with the O1 to the closest ring atom of 2.927(3) Å. Anion−π and its analogous lone pair–aromatic interactions stabilized by electrostatic or ion-induced polarization forces prove to be important in the construction of supramolecular architectures and in molecular recognition. A number of DFT calculations and CSD search studies on anion−π confirmed the presence of such interactions with binding energies (20–50 kJ mol–1) comparable to that of hydrogen bonds. In the present case, the values of F(CF3CO2 –)···centroidpyrimidyl (3.151–3.213 Å) are comparable to that of F(CF3CO2 –)···centroidpyrazinyl (3.042–3.660 Å) in pyrazinyl-based metal complexes reported by us, and also are in good agreement with the results of a CSD survey study [F(R-F)···centroidpyrimidyl mean 3.166 Å, R = any atom of the Periodic Table] by Reedijk et al. The distances F···C/N(ring atoms) range from 3.072(4) to 3.767(4) Å, and the angle of the X(F)···π axis to the plane of the pyrimidyl cycle (φ) ranges from 74.0° to 84.6° (see Table ). For the O(CF3CO2 –)···πpyrimidyl, the O1···centroidpyrimidyl of 3.469 Å is comparable to that O(CF3CO2 –)···pyrazinyl of 3.030 in [Ag(sulfonyldipyrazine)2(CF3CO2)]∞ due to the similar electronic deficiencies between pyrimidyl and pyrazinyl rings, the detailed geometries of which are listed in Table for comparison. The formed net layers further stack along the c axis to form a 3-D framework with the lattice water molecules and the free CF3CO2 – anions (O3-containing) embedded within the interlayer interstices ().

Complex 2 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. There are six independent Ag(I) ions in the asymmetric unit with different coordination geometries, the distorted tetrahedral N 4-coordination geometry of Ag1 and Ag3 ions, the tetrahedral N 3 O-coordination geometry of Ag5 and Ag6, the planar triangle N 2 O-geometry of Ag2, and the pyramidal N 2 O 3 -geometry of Ag4 (Figure ). The triflate anions exhibit weak bonding (to Ag2 and Ag4 with the Ag···O lying within the 2.700(6)–2.760(5) Å range), strong bonding (to Ag4 and Ag6 with the Ag–O lying within the 2.456(6)–2.563(7) Å range) ability, as well as free lattice charge balance (O12-containing) in the crystalline structure of 2 (Figure a). The N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging DprS exhibit six sets of molecular dimensions due to the various Ag(I) ions (Ag1 to Ag6) bound. The N···C distances (D, 2.729(2)–2.841(3) Å) and the dihedral angles (81.89(3)–87.62(3)°) between two pyrimidyl rings of DprS vary in a narrow range, respectively, which are comparable to these in 1 (Table ). The values of D are well below the sum of involved atoms' van der Waals radii (3.220 Å). In comparison, the S4-containing DprS exhibits the shortest D of 2.729(2) Å, the smallest C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle of 97.8(3)°, and the largest dihedral angle of 87.62(3)° close to 90°. As listed in Table , the molecule dimensions of DprS substantially indicate that the conformation with the dihedral angle between two pyrimidyl rings close to 90° is favorable for the N···C contact, engendering a shorter N···C distance and a smaller C(sp 2 )–S–C(sp 2 ) angle. As that in complex 1, the D1 values commonly are shorter than that of D2. In the S1-containing DprS of complex 2, D1 is 0.041 Å less than D2 (Table ).

As shown in Figure a, each Ag1 ion bonds to two N atoms and an O(C2F5CO2 –) atom, and links to another C2F5CO2 – at O3···Ag1 of 2.699(2) Å. For Ag2, two C2F5CO2 – and one DprS ligand provide two O atoms and one N atom to link to the ion, while a third C2F5CO2 – exhibits weak bonding to the metal center (O3···Ag2a 2.620(2) Å). Regarding the DprS ligand, each DprS links two symmetry-related Ag1 ions and one Ag2, adopting the same N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode as that in complexes 1–2. In the present case, considering the weak Ag···O(C2F5CO2 –), the C2F5CO2 – anions (O1-containing and O3-containing) exhibit a η1:η1:μ2- and a η1:η2:μ3-ligating modes, which combine the N,N′,N″-μ3 DprS to furnish a 2-D sheet-like structure almost parallel to the bc plane, as shown in Figure . Treating the DprS as a 3-connected node, the Ag atoms each as a connected node, the strong μ2-bridged C2F5CO2 – (O1-containing) as a linker, a topological net different from that of 1–2 is formed, as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: Regarding the anion (C2F5CO2 –)−πpyrimidyl interaction, as shown in Figure a, the O3-containing pentafluoropropanoic shows F···π and O···π contacts with two proximate pyrimidyl rings at the F22···centroid of 3.305 Å and O4···centroid of 3.324 Å, respectively. The O1-containing pentafluoropropanoic approaches one pyrimidyl ring with the O1···centroidpyrimidyl of 3.187 Å, and the values of O1···C(the closest ring atom) and φ angle are 3.127(3) Å and 82.0°, respectively. For comparison, the F22(C2F5CO2 –)···centroid distance (3.305 Å) is comparable to that of the F(CF3CO2 –/CF3SO3 –)···centroid in 1–2 (3.151–3.213 Å) and are also comparable to the results of a CSD survey study [F(R-F)···centroidpyrimidyl mean 3.166 Å, R = any atom of the Periodic Table]. The O(C2F5CO2 –)···centroid distances (3.187–3.324 Å) are well comparable to that of the O(CF3CO2 –)···centroid (3.469 Å) in complex 1, and the detailed metric parameters of the anion−π interactions are shown in Table for comparison. By these multiple anion−π driving forces, a pleated sheet-like layer thus is formed (). Careful scrutiny also reveals that each DprS is in contact with three separated anions from different directions (Figure b), two of which on both sides of the standing pyrimidyl ring exhibit asymmetry O···π (O···centroid: 3.187 Å, 3.324 Å) contacts, leading to the smaller dihedral angle of 72.55(6)° compared to those of 1–2. The third C2F5CO2 – contacts with the base ring (F22···centroid 3.305 Å), which drives the ring away and explains well the longer N···C separation (2.911(5) Å) compared to those in 1–2 (2.729(2)–2.841(3) Å). Thus, a compressed DprS results with respect to that of 1–2.

elements.content: Complex 4 crystallizes in the orthorhombic P212121 space group. In complex 4, an infinite tape-like structure along the a axis is formed with the N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging DprS. As shown in Figure a, the four coordinated Ag(I) ion (N3O-geometry) with three DprS and one nitrate around function as a 3-connected node, while each DprS ligand linking to three symmetry related Ag(I) ions acts as another 3-connected node, thus forming a ladder-like coordination polymer (Figure b) that is sharply different from these of 1 and 2. For the DprS, D is 2.888(2) Å, which is larger than that in 1–2 (2.729(2)–2.841(3) Å) but shorter than that of 3 (2.911(5) Å). Thus, the value of (sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle (102.61(1)°) is reasonably larger than that of 1 and 2 (97.49(2)–100.8(3)°) but smaller than that 103.2(7)° of 3. The detailed dimensions of DprS are listed in Table for comparison. Regarding the anion−π interaction, the NO3 – bound to the Ag(I) ion (Ag1–O1 2.460(2) Å) is sandwiched by two pyrimidyl rings from separate DprS on the same tape moiety, forming an infinite ···pyrimidyl···NO3 –··· array. As shown in Figure a, the O1(NO3 –)···πpyrimidyl contact has O1···centroid distances of 3.345 Å and 3.462 Å, which are slightly longer than the mean O(NO3 –)···centroidpyrimidyl distance of 3.19 Å from a CSD statistical study. The distances of O(NO3 –)···C/N(ring atoms) lie within the range of 3.228(3)–4.140(3) Å (Table ).

elements.content: Complex 5 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group. An infinite tape-like structure similar to complex 2 (Figure ) is formed along the [101̅] direction (Figure a). In contrast to the triflate anion in 2, the perchlorate has a weaker coordination ability and is deposited away from the Ag(I); thus, the Ag(I) ions of 5 exhibit just three coordination geometries with different numbers of DprS ligands around: Ag1(N,N-linear geometry), Ag2(N 4 -tetrahedral geometry), and Ag3(N 3-pyramidal geometry), rather than the complicated coordination geometries of Ag1 to Ag6 in 2. Complex 5 also can be regarded as an isostructure of 2 having the same topological structure as the DprS as a 3-connected node, the Ag atoms each as a connected node (Figure b). Three independent DprS molecules (S1-, S2- and S3-containing, Figure a) are revealed in 5. The values of D lie within the range of 2.754(2)–2.817(1) Å, and the dihedral angles vary from 83.89(5)° to 88.96(5)° (the S3-containing DprS is not included due to positional disordered reasons). The S2-containing DprS has a shorter D (2.754(2) Å), a smaller C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle of 99.1(6)°, and a dihedral of 88.96(5)° close to 90°, compared to those of S1-containing. In S2-containing DprS, the D1 (1.734(1) Å) is 0.062 Å much less than the D2 (1.796(1) Å), the largest difference between the pairs of S–C(sp2) bonds of DprS in complexes 1–5 (Table ).

elements.content: Viewed down the b direction, the tape-like cationic coordination moieties are stacked with the Cl3-containing perchlorate anions embedded within the interstices. Adjacent two tapes interconnect through O(ClO4 –)···πpyrimidyl interactions, as shown in Figure b. The Cl3-containing perchlorate is embraced by two pyrimidyl rings from separate DprS on one tape moiety and the third ring from the opposite tape to form a multiple O(ClO4 –)···πpyrimidyl interaction (O···centroidpyrimidyl from 3.286 Å to 3.522 Å, Table ) to link the tapes together, engendering a cationic layer (Figure b). The formed layers are almost parallel and stacked with the other two perchlorate (Cl1- and Cl2-containing) embedded within the interstices, wherein the anions (Cl1- and Cl2-containing) are stabilized by Ag···O, C–H···O hydrogen-bonding and/or O(ClO4 –)···πpyrimidyl interactions (Figure ). For the Cl2-containing ClO4 –, the O7 atom anchors to one tape moiety via Ag1···O7 (2.785(1) Å) and O7···π (O···centroid 3.308 Å) interactions. In this complex, the mean of O···centroidpyrimidyl is 3.38 Å, comparable to the CSD survey result of O(ClO4 –)···centroidpyrimidyl (mean 3.17 Å) but is slightly longer than O(ClO4 –)···centroid(1,2,4,5‑tetrazinyl) (mean 2.91 Å) due to the less π-acidic nature of the pyrimidyl ring. The detailed anion−π geometries are listed in Table for comparison.

elements.content: To have an insight into the intramolecular Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl interaction of the DprS in the metal–organic frameworks of the silver(I) complexes 1–5, we conducted a periodic structure crystal orbital calculation based on DFT by use the X-ray data of complex 4. As the Mulliken population for the N,N′,N″-μ3 bridging DprS shown in Figure a, the net charge on the N atom (1-positional) involved in the Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl contact is −0.561 |e|, which is 0.019 |e| less than the other N atom (3-positional N bound to Ag(I)) of the same ring. This indicates that the electron transfer from the N to the C of the N···C contact is stronger than that from 3-positional N to the Ag(I) bound to. In contrast, the charges of the two Ag(I)-bound N atoms of the other ring are the same, −0.542 |e|. Meanwhile, the charge on the C atom (2′-positional) involved in the N···C contact is 0.318 |e|, which is 0.026 |e| less than that 2-positional C atom of the other pyrimidyl ring. This can be attributed to the nucleophile–electrophile N···C interaction, and the charge transfer is estimated to be 0.02 |e|. The highest occupied crystal orbital (HOCO) and the lowest unoccupied crystal orbital (LUCO) refer to the orbital of the AgNO3 and π orbital of one pyrimidyl ring, respectively (Figure b). No evidence of the delocalization of the sulfur lone pair electrons is found in 10 frontier orbitals (from HOCO-4 to LUCO+4). The delocalization of the sulfur lone pair over the symmetry apt pyrimidyl π-system that was indicated to combine the electrostatic N···C interaction to stabilize the nonplanar conformation of the free PhpyS and Prpys is not found in the periodic structure of the DprS in complex 4. Apparently, the affinity is mainly contributed by electrostatic interaction, a nucleophile–electrophile N···C interaction.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Investigation on the N⋅⋅⋅C Interaction of DprS in This Study

To have an insight into the intramolecular Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl interaction of the DprS in the metal-organic frameworks of the silver(I) complexes 1-5, we conducted a periodic structure crystal orbital calculation based on DFT by use the X-ray data of complex 4. As the Mulliken population for the N,N',N"-μ3 bridging DprS shown in Figure a, the net charge on the N atom (1-positional) involved in the Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl contact is -0.561 |e|, which is 0.019 |e| less than the other N atom (3-positional N bound to Ag(I)) of the same ring. This indicates that the electron transfer from the N to the C of the N⋅⋅⋅C contact is stronger than that from 3-positional N to the Ag(I) bound to. In contrast, the charges of the two Ag(I)-bound N atoms of the other ring are the same, -0.542 |e|. Meanwhile, the charge on the C atom (2'-positional) involved in the N⋅⋅⋅C contact is 0.318 |e|, which is 0.026 |e| less than that 2-positional C atom of the other pyrimidyl ring. This can be attributed to the nucleophile-electrophile N⋅⋅⋅C interaction, and the charge transfer is estimated to be 0.02 |e|. The highest occupied crystal orbital (HOCO) and the lowest unoccupied crystal orbital (LUCO) refer to the orbital of the AgNO3 and π orbital of one pyrimidyl ring, respectively (Figure b). No evidence of the delocalization of the sulfur lone pair electrons is found in 10 frontier orbitals (from HOCO-4 to LUCO+4). The delocalization of the sulfur lone pair over the symmetry apt pyrimidyl π-system that was indicated to combine the electrostatic N⋅⋅⋅C interaction to stabilize the nonplanar conformation of the free PhpyS and Prpys is not found in the periodic structure of the DprS in complex 4. Apparently, the affinity is mainly contributed by electrostatic interaction, a nucleophile-electrophile N⋅⋅⋅C interaction.

elements.content: The IR spectra of the present series of complexes indicate that the coordination of DprS with silver(I) salts affect the vibration of ligand DprS only to a minor extent. As to the ν(CN), DprS ligand exhibits sharp and strong peaks at 1551 and 1388 cm–1, while complexes 1–5 show the same peaks at about 1553 and 1377 cm–1, respectively (). Moreover, there are two weak double bands around 806–824 cm–1 and 748–770 cm–1 in complexes 1–5 and the free DprS ligand, characteristic of the δ(C–S–C) bending and ν(C–S) stretching frequency, respectively. The almost same peaks of complexes 1–5 are consistent with the same conformation of DprS in them. The ambiguous change of the measured values with respect to the free DprS ligand indicates that the free DprS may adopt a similar conformation to that in complexes 1–5, as that in free phenyl-pyridyl sulfide (PhpyS) and pyrimidyl-pyridyl sulfide (PrpyS) indicated by Bruno et al.
elements.clean_text:
IR Spectroscopic Study

The IR spectra of the present series of complexes indicate that the coordination of DprS with silver(I) salts affect the vibration of ligand DprS only to a minor extent. As to the ν(CN), DprS ligand exhibits sharp and strong peaks at 1551 and 1388 cm-1, while complexes 1-5 show the same peaks at about 1553 and 1377 cm-1, respectively (). Moreover, there are two weak double bands around 806-824 cm-1 and 748-770 cm-1 in complexes 1-5 and the free DprS ligand, characteristic of the δ(C-S-C) bending and ν(C-S) stretching frequency, respectively. The almost same peaks of complexes 1-5 are consistent with the same conformation of DprS in them. The ambiguous change of the measured values with respect to the free DprS ligand indicates that the free DprS may adopt a similar conformation to that in complexes 1-5, as that in free phenyl-pyridyl sulfide (PhpyS) and pyrimidyl-pyridyl sulfide (PrpyS) indicated by Bruno et al.

elements.content: Fluorescence experiments for the DprS ligand and the silver(I) complexes 1–5 were carried out at room temperature in the solid state. DprS exhibits a fluorescent emission peak at 404 nm (λex = 341 nm, Figure S6). The similar emission at about 400 nm (λex = 341 nm, λmax: 397 nm (1), 400 nm (2), 406 nm (3), 398 nm (4), 398 nm (5)) is respectively observed for the complexes 1–5, which can be ascribed to the intraligand π*−π transition of the ligand. In contrast to the free ligand, complexes 1–2 exhibit broad and weak bands centered at 468 nm, while complex 3 has the relatively intense emission at 467 nm, all of which are tentatively assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The results indicate that the emission property of the silver(I) complexes of DprS is modified by metal coordination. Further experiments aimed at structure–property relationships are in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Emission Properties

Fluorescence experiments for the DprS ligand and the silver(I) complexes 1-5 were carried out at room temperature in the solid state. DprS exhibits a fluorescent emission peak at 404 nm (λex = 341 nm, Figure S6). The similar emission at about 400 nm (λex = 341 nm, λmax: 397 nm (1), 400 nm (2), 406 nm (3), 398 nm (4), 398 nm (5)) is respectively observed for the complexes 1-5, which can be ascribed to the intraligand π*-π transition of the ligand. In contrast to the free ligand, complexes 1-2 exhibit broad and weak bands centered at 468 nm, while complex 3 has the relatively intense emission at 467 nm, all of which are tentatively assigned to the ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT). The results indicate that the emission property of the silver(I) complexes of DprS is modified by metal coordination. Further experiments aimed at structure-property relationships are in progress.

elements.content: In summary, a series of silver(I) complexes 1–5 of di-2-pryimidyl sulfide, namely, {[Ag2(DprS)2(CF3CO2)](CF3CO2)·2H2O}∞ (1), {[Ag6(DprS)6(CF3SO3)5](CF3SO3)·3.5H2O}∞ (2), {[Ag2(DprS)(C2F5CO2)2]∞ (3), [Ag(DprS)(NO3)∞ (4), and {[Ag3(DprS)3](ClO4)3}∞ (5), have been obtained and characterized. The infinite 1-D tape-like (in 1–2, 4–5) and 2-D network (in 3) with different topological structures are observed. The conformation restriction of the semirigid DprS derived by the intramolecular Npyrimidyl···Cpyrimidyl affinity plays a crucial role in construction of the coordination architectures in the solid state of complexes 1–5. The multidentate DprS thus adopts an unvaried N,N′,N″-μ3 ligation mode with a nonplanar conformation in these complexes, even though the anions are different. Structural analysis implies that the two pyrimidyl rings of DprS in an orthogonal orientation (dihedral angle of 90°) are favorable for the N···C contact, leading to a relatively shorter N···C distance with a smaller C(sp2)–S–C(sp2) angle. The periodic structure crystal orbital calculation indicates that the electrostatic factor is the main attribution for such an N···C affinity. Intramolecular anion−πpyrimidyl contact exhibits a subtle influence on the precise microarchitectures of these supramolecular aggregations of complexes 1–5. The coordination chemistry of the rich N diheterocyclic sulfide is worthy of further investigation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a series of silver(I) complexes 1-5 of di-2-pryimidyl sulfide, namely, {[Ag2(DprS)2(CF3CO2)](CF3CO2)⋅2H2O}∞ (1), {[Ag6(DprS)6(CF3SO3)5](CF3SO3)⋅3.5H2O}∞ (2), {[Ag2(DprS)(C2F5CO2)2]∞ (3), [Ag(DprS)(NO3)∞ (4), and {[Ag3(DprS)3](ClO4)3}∞ (5), have been obtained and characterized. The infinite 1-D tape-like (in 1-2, 4-5) and 2-D network (in 3) with different topological structures are observed. The conformation restriction of the semirigid DprS derived by the intramolecular Npyrimidyl⋅⋅⋅Cpyrimidyl affinity plays a crucial role in construction of the coordination architectures in the solid state of complexes 1-5. The multidentate DprS thus adopts an unvaried N,N',N"-μ3 ligation mode with a nonplanar conformation in these complexes, even though the anions are different. Structural analysis implies that the two pyrimidyl rings of DprS in an orthogonal orientation (dihedral angle of 90°) are favorable for the N⋅⋅⋅C contact, leading to a relatively shorter N⋅⋅⋅C distance with a smaller C(sp2)-S-C(sp2) angle. The periodic structure crystal orbital calculation indicates that the electrostatic factor is the main attribution for such an N⋅⋅⋅C affinity. Intramolecular anion-πpyrimidyl contact exhibits a subtle influence on the precise microarchitectures of these supramolecular aggregations of complexes 1-5. The coordination chemistry of the rich N diheterocyclic sulfide is worthy of further investigation.
